About This Game



You are a Grey Warden, one of the last of a legendary order of guardians. With the return of an ancient foe and the kingdom engulfed in civil war, you have been chosen by fate to unite the shattered lands and slay the archdemon once and for all.

A Stunning World to Explore
  • BioWare’s deepest universe to date with over 80 hours of gameplay and more than double the size and scope of Mass Effect
  • Travel throughout dozens of environments and fully immerse yourself in a shattered world that is on the brink of utter annihilation
  • An epic story that is completely shaped and reactive to your play style
Complex Moral Choices
  • There are no easy choices
  • Tailor your Dragon Age: Origins experience from the very beginning by choose from six different Origin Stories
  • Decide how to handle complex issues like murder, genocide, betrayal, and the possession/sacrificing of children without the security of a good/bad slider to tell you what to do
Full Character Customization
  • Sculpt your hero in your own image or fantasy
  • Elaborate character creator allows you to create your own hero unique from anyone else
  • Shape your character’s personality and morality based on the choices you make throughout the game
Engage in Bone-Crushing, Visceral Combat
  • Battle against massive and terrifying creatures
  • Unleash legendary powers and choose from over 100 different magical spells and skills
  • Experience the adrenaline rush of brutal combat, beheading your foes or casting spells that make enemies explode from within

  Blood Dragon Armor
Commissioned by an infamous Nevarran dragon hunter, this armor was crafted in a time when dragons had almost been hunted to extinction. Infused with their blood, the armor gained notoriety after the hunter died at the hands of men rather than the dragons it was designed to protect him from.
  • Grants exceptional protection in combat
  • Armor will be usable in BioWare's upcoming science fiction epic, Mass Effect 2

  The Stone Prisoner
The darkspawn-infested village of Honnleath holds a secret: the forgotten stone figure at the town’s heart is a powerful golem frozen in time. Free the creature and reveal a storied quest to unlock its power and mysterious past.
Download The Stone Prisoner and gain access to Shale, a mighty stone golem who can join the party and travel throughout Dragon Age: Origins. One of the most powerful characters in the game, Shale comes with a rich back story, extensive voice acting, and a unique follower quest to explore. The Stone Prisoner also includes new environments, items, and hours of additional gameplay that adds to the Dragon Age: Origins campaign.
  • A powerful new party member to aid in the epic quest to save Ferelden from the Blight
  • New areas, including the troubled village of Honnleath
  • New achievements, items, and unique insights into the Dragon Age: Origins storyline
READ MORE

System Requirements

    Minimum:
    • OS: Windows XP (SP3) or Windows Vista (SP1) or Windows 7
    • Processor: Intel Core 2 Single 1.6 Ghz Processor (or equivalent) or AMD 64 2.0 GHz Processor (or equivalent)
    • Memory: 1GB (1.5 GB Vista and Windows 7)
    • Graphics: ATI Radeon X850 256MB or NVIDIA GeForce 6600 GT 128MB or greater (Windows Vista: Radeon X1550 256 MB or NVidia GeForce 7600GT 256MB)
    • DirectX®: DirectX (November 2007)
    • Hard Drive: 20 GB HD space
    • Sound: Direct X Compatible Sound Card
    Recommended:
    • OS: Windows XP (SP3) or Windows Vista (SP1) or Windows 7
    • Processor: Intel Core 2 Duo 2.4 Ghz or AMD Phenom II X2 Dual-Core 2.7 Ghz Processor or equivalent
    • Memory: 2 GB (3GB Vista and Windows 7)
    • Graphics: ATI 3850 512 MB or NVidia 8800GTS 512MB or greater
    • DirectX®: DirectX (November 2007)
    • Hard Drive: 20 GB HD space
    • Sound: Direct X Compatible Sound Card

Sir Figgy Starbuckle
2,291 products in account
114 reviews
Recommended
125.6 hrs on record
Posted: June 14
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase
3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

Enchantment! Enchantment!

Described as the spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate by former Bioware CEO Ray Muzyka, Dragon Age: Origins was easily one of the most hotly anticipated releases of the 2009 Christmas calendar. Party-based role playing games, which where immensely popular in the late nineties and early two thousands, had long since fallen out of favor with most big publishing houses thanks to the rise and popularity of the home console. With their lengthy novella like texts and lethargic combat mechanics (often involving a lot of pausing, lining up of abilities and buffs and strategic character placements on the battlefield) they were simply no longer du jour. PC piracy at the time also played a large contributing factor towards why most PC-centric development houses were jumping ship and abandoning the PC, so to the many fans of this genre of RPG we simply had to contend with the fact that party-based role playing games were, in all probability, dead in the water since they are often incredibly difficult games to replicate, without making the game an entirely cumbersome affair, on a home console, without the use of a mouse and a keyboard.

Take that you archdemon you! 
A Screenshot of Dragon Age: Origins
By: Sir Figgy Starbuckle

Sadly the success of Dragon Age: Origins on the PC did not herald a second coming as the subsequent sequels in the franchise devolved into a more action-orientated affair. It would be another four years before we saw the genre gain popularity once again thanks to independent studios using crowd-funding and early access to breath life back into the genre (Obsidian's and InXile's Kickstarted Pillars of Eternity, Wasteland 2 and upcoming Torment: Tides of Numenera to Larian Studios early access title Divinity: Original Sin). Dragon Age: Origins is a great entry point for those unfamiliar with the genre or find the older classics upon which the game takes many of its ques (Baldur's Gate 1 and 2) a little too harsh on the eye or feel that they are a tad too outdated for the modern era. Once again Bioware shows its usual flair when it comes to world building which are often filled to the brim with a detailed narrative, fully fleshed out characters and an engrossing lore to anchor the world and give it a presence. Being a modern game with a far bigger budget all narrative is now fully voiced and accompanied by impressive cut scenes which drive the story forward removing one of the barriers to the genre - the tome like texts that were often used to drive the narrative forward.

Was it not good for you Morrigan? 
A Screenshot of Dragon Age: Origins
By: Sir Figgy Starbuckle

Where Dragon Age: Origins succeeds admirably though is through the origin tale it tells of the hero you select at the start of the game. There are a host of options to choose from depending which route you plan to cover at the start (mage, human, dwarf or elf) with each race getting its very own opening chapter which fleshes out the lore of each race wonderfully before dovetailing comfortably into the games main plot which sees your hero being recruited by the head of the Grey Wardens, a fabled group of warriors who must unite the Kingdom of Ferelden before an impending demon invasion know as blight tears the kingdom asunder. As with most party-based role playing games the canvas upon which Dragon Age: Origins etches its tale is broad and sweeping and filled with a host of memorable characters (although it is no where near as large a game as the classics of yore). As the tale progresses the player will eventually form a party of four from a host of characters that you, the leader, can recruit on your travels. You will always have access to them in your party even as the roster grows, each coming with their own strengths and weaknesses so it will be up to you to play mix and match until you have found a formula that suits you best. Like your main character you will also have a hand in dealing how each character develops over the course of the stories arc which adds nicely to the replay value should you consider to go another round after the main campaign is completed. While the party mechanic is filled with a host of well rounded characters my only gripe here is that you will need to micro manage your party right down to who gets to take a ♥♥♥♥ first because on any difficulty level above easy characters sometimes have a hard time obeying the commands you just gave them and even if you use the tactical slots given to you, which are unlocked the further you progress, they still often go off on a tangent and have to be quickly brought back into line lest the party forfeit the battle.

Interested parties 
A Screenshot of Dragon Age: Origins
By: Sir Figgy Starbuckle

If you own the Ultimate Edition - all DLC previously offered as in game purchases through the game client is included. Each DLC is its own self contained adventure that lasts roughly 2-4 hrs depending on your playstyle. None of the DLC is unfortunately up to the same level of excellence as the main campaign but completing either of them does include some valuable gear and equipment that can be used in the main game or carried over into Dragon Age: Awakenings - the full expansion pack that accompanies the Dragon Age: Origins Ultimate Edition. Graphically, Dragon Age: Origins has aged particularly well. It was never a looker to begin with but 6 years on from release they are still serviceable if a little brown, muddy and drab. Developed using the Lycium engine, this engine was eventually put out to pasture and replaced with the Frostbite engine for Dragon Age Inquisition. The game is also served by a fully orchestrated soundtrack which is hits just the right amount of epic during key moments of the adventure.

There really isn't much to fault with Biowares return to dark, gritty heroic fantasy. It is a real throwback to the good old days of RPG gaming and it enthralls and entertains at every turn and it is certainly in my top favorite RPG games of all time so I have no qualms recommending it as an essential purchase for all RPG lovers the world over. If you haven't given the game a spin yet or don't own it in your library I highly recommend you purchase it during the sale or give it a spin soonest. You won't be disappointed.

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater

Not Recommended

Posted: August 13
Please DO NOT buy this version of the game. Get the Ultimate Version instead.

Although it is an amazing game, there is no easy way to purchase all of the DLC for it through Steam. At regular price the base game costs $20, with the much needed Awakening DLC costing another $20. The other 8 expansions for this game can't be purchased through steam, but rather through Bioware points. If you decide to pick those up, it'll cost another $60 out of your pocket.

Instead of paying the $100 you'd need to spend on this version, buy the EXACT SAME THING for $30 in the Ultimate Version.

FinalFantasyType-0
486 products in account
50 reviews
Recommended
34.1 hrs on record
Posted: July 10
Dragon Age: Origins is a role-playing video game developed by BioWare's Edmonton studio and published by Electronic Arts. It is the first game in the Dragon Age franchise. Set in the fictional kingdom of Ferelden during a period of civil strife, the player assumes the role of a warrior, mage or rogue coming from an elven, human, or dwarven background who must unite the kingdom to fight an impending invasion by demonic forces. BioWare describes Dragon Age: Origins as a "dark heroic fantasy set in a unique world", and a spiritual successor to their Baldur's Gate series of games, which took place in the Forgotten Realms Campaign Setting of the Dungeons & Dragons franchise.

Damn, this game is great. The story is very interesting. This game has many choices, so this game doesn't get boring when you are replaying it. Fighting and party systems are very good. I really like fast traveling idea. You can go fast through the map, but you can still be attacked. I like how bad guys change their personality when they lose a fight. This game is really enjoyable.

When you are traveling characters talk to each other. So one time to girls in my party started talking about breasts. I didn't start a new mission till girls stopped talking.

By the way, in Denerim there is ♥♥♥♥♥ house so you can have fun. Sadly you won't see any action.

Lunaril
561 products in account
177 reviews
Recommended
1.4 hrs on record
Posted: June 1
The game that started a franchise. Dragon Age Origins brings us to the kingdom of Ferelden, caught in an epic battle against the Darkspawn horde, led by an Archdemon. I can't say much more without giving away the story, though I will say get ready for intrigue, mysteries, betrayal, redemption, and more as you join forces with Wandering and Mysterious strangers, Brothers and Sisters in Arms, and people you help along the way. Dragon Age Origins has just the right blend of RPG elements, and plot driven story line, to make it fun and interesting without letting you get to sidetracked. If you have any interest in the series at all, you must start with Origins. There are several DLC packs available for DA: Origins, which further the main story, provide backstory and history, as well as introduce new companions. Playing with all available DLC is recommended for the full experience. Having played DA: Origins, as well as DA 2 on the PS3, I look forward to reliving those experiences on the steam version of DA: Origins. It is that good!
